articleText:
Title: Trump administration must pay Snap food benefits, US judges say

URL Source: https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cr433x9zqq4o?at_medium=RSS&at_campaign=rss

Published Time: 2025-10-31T18:32:44.079Z

Markdown Content:
Trump administration must continue food aid during shutdown, US judges say
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

13 hours ago

Jessica Murphy

![Image 1: Universal Images Group via Getty Images A sign on a grocery store fridge reads "We accepts SNAP food stamp program' in both English and Spanish. Frozen food is seen in the background. ](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/850f/live/e6d866a0-b686-11f0-b027-61021c9d4006.jpg.webp)Universal Images Group via Getty Images

The Trump administration cannot suspend food aid used by about 42 million low-income Americans during the US government shutdown, two federal judges have ruled.

The rulings said the government must pay for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits using emergency funds.

US President Donald Trump said in response that he had instructed government lawyers to ask the courts how the administration could legally fund Snap, adding: "Even if we get immediate guidance, it will unfortunately be delayed."

While individual US states administer the benefits, the programme uses money from the federal government, which has been unfunded and shut down since 1 October.

The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) says it will not distribute food assistance funds in November due to the shutdown, saying "the well has run dry".

The Snap programme works by giving people reloadable debit cards that they can use to buy essential grocery items. A family of four on average receives $715 (£540) per month, which breaks down to a little less than $6 (£4.50) per day, per person.

Several states have pledged to use their own funds to cover any shortfall, but have been warned by the federal government that they will not be reimbursed.

[Dozens of US states sued the Trump administration](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cx2px0zmz8mo) over its plans to halt funding, hoping to force it to use a roughly $6bn (£4.5bn) emergency contingency fund for Snap, also known as food stamps.

Trump said on Truth Social on Friday: "If we are given the appropriate legal direction by the Court, it will BE MY HONOR to provide the funding."

Massachusetts US District Judge Indira Talwani wrote in her decision that the states that sued were likely to win in court on their claim that "Congress intended the funding of Snap benefits, at a reduced rate if necessary, when appropriated funds prove insufficient".

The judge said the administration must access the contingency funding to pay the benefits and had until Monday to report back to the court on whether they will authorise at least partial benefits for November.

Judge Talwani also wrote that the Trump administration "erred in concluding" that the USDA was blocked by law from tapping the emergency reserves in the contingency fund when there was a lapse in federal funding.

The USDA had said those reserves were insufficient to pay full benefits, which cost $8.5bn-$9bn each month. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins had said she would only use the fund for an emergency such as a natural disaster.

Even if the government turns to the contingency fund, it would only be able to cover about 60% of beneficiaries in a single month, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities (CBPP), a think-tank focused on policies that help low-income families.

Judge Talwani also asked the administration to report back on whether it will pay full benefits for the month by moving money from other programmes, similar to the administration transferring military research funds earlier this month to pay members of the armed forces.

In a separate ruling, Rhode Island federal Judge John J McConnell Jr ordered the Trump administration to make full Snap benefit payments by 3 November.

The judge said the contingency fund - in addition to a separate $23bn fund created through the Agricultural Adjustment Act amendments of 1935 - could be used to make full payments.

If the government chooses not to use these other funds, Judge McConnell Jr ruled the government had to make a partial payment using the total amount of the contingency funds by 5 November.

Separately in Rhode Island, a lawsuit was brought by a number of US cities and non-government organisations that sued over what they called the "unlawful suspension" of the programme.

"There is no doubt and it is beyond argument that irreparable harm will begin to occur if it hasn't already occurred in the terror it has caused some people about the availability of funding for food, for their family," Judge McConnell Jr said.

The USDA did not comment on the decisions. The BBC has also contacted the Office of Management and Budget for comment.

At a news conference before the rulings were issued, Rollins said "we're looking at all the options" when asked whether the administration would comply if courts required it to release funds.

On Friday, the group behind the lawsuit in Rhode Island said that the ruling was "a lifeline for millions of families, seniors, and veterans who depend on Snap to put food on the table".

It added: "It reaffirms a fundamental principle: no administration can use hunger as a political weapon."

Republicans and Democrats have traded blame for the federal shutdown, which will soon enter its second month, while there has not been any meaningful progress toward a deal.

Two federal judges have ruled that the Trump administration must continue providing Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits to approximately 42 million low-income Americans during the ongoing government shutdown. The administration had planned to suspend these benefits due to a lack of federal funding since October 1. The judges ordered the use of emergency contingency funds and other available resources to ensure the continuation of benefits. The USDA had claimed these reserves were insufficient for full payments, but the courts mandated at least partial payments by early November. The rulings came after multiple states and organizations sued the administration, arguing that suspending Snap benefits would cause irreparable harm.

The ISB recognizes the critical nature of maintaining public order and minimizing unrest during periods of governmental instability, such as a shutdown. The court's decision to mandate the continuation of Snap benefits is a significant legal and political challenge that could undermine the administration's authority and strategic objectives. The potential for public dissent and unrest among low-income populations is high if food aid is disrupted. The ISB must assess the broader implications of this ruling on the administration's ability to manage fiscal resources and maintain control over federal programs.
